results.title: Rosalie's journey
results.brief_description: The film presents Rosalie (Ngarla) Kunoth-Monks speaking for the first time in her Arrente language. It tells the other side to the film which in 1955 was one of a kind: first full colour feature film and first to feature Aboriginal actors with speaking parts. The program is about Rosalie’s life before and after ‘Jedda’, her life in central Australia as a young woman and the profound cultural challenges she faced when selected by Charles Chauvel to play the lead role in ‘Jedda’ in 1955. Includes archival footage and excerpts from ‘Jedda’ including some b&w scenes.

results.title: Faces
results.brief_description:
Sue Ford’s experimental film “Faces” consists of portraits of the artist and her friends and acquaintances. Ford filmed each subject for roughly 25 seconds, using a wind-up Bolex camera that framed their faces in close-up. Variously self-conscious, serious, amused and distracted, the camera captures every small gesture, expression and flicker of emotion on the person’s face. The result is an examination of portraiture and the performance of identity, demonstrating the artist’s interest in using the camera to capture reality, time and change.

Participants in the film include artists Micky Allan, Bonita Ely and Paul Reed, among others.

results.title: Nice coloured girls [DVD] (A)
results.brief_description: Nice Coloured Girls uses experimental film techniques in an examination of the new urban ritual of taking white men for a ride. No longer the victims of these men, the women are still trapped by economic necessity. “Nice Coloured Girls” uses a clever juxtaposition of images and voice over of extracts from early journals of white settlers to compare aspects of the relationship between Aboriginal women and white men in the past and in the 1980s. Cast includes Gayle Mabo, Cheryl Pit, Janelle Court, Fiona George and Lindsay McCorrmack. (Awards: London, Berlin, Toronto)

results.title: Black chicks talking [Widescreen] (A)
results.creator_credit: BungaburBungabura Productions, SBS Independent, Bain Stewart and Leah Purcell
results.brief_description: Performer and writer Leah Purcell talks with five very different Indigenous women - Rosanna Angus, Kathryn Hay, Deborah Mailman, Cilla Malone and Tammy Williams - about what it means to be Aboriginal in Australia today. In a series of individual interviews and at one lively dinner party, the women frankly share their life experiences and opinions. Though their backgrounds are extremely diverse, common themes of culture, family, racism and denial run through their stories, as does the ongoing personal and social legacy of past government polices of forced removal. The result is a passionate and challenging exploration of black identity. Teachers notes available through Film Australia at: http://www.filmaust.com.au/programs/default.asp?content=teachers_notes

results.title: Small island, big fight (A)
results.creator_credit: Junjidys Productions, Film Australia, Australian Broadcasting Corporation, Rosemary Hesp, Trevor Graham and Aven S Noah
results.brief_description: …Where I come from is Murray Island. We call it Mer. The home of the famous Mabo land rights case. We won that battle, but now we’ve got a new fight on our hands…this time with outside fishing fleets over who can profit from our waters. (Aven S. Noah) Situated on the eastern side of the Torres Strait between Papua New Guinea and Australia, Murray Island or Mer, is home to around 450 indigenous people with each family belonging to one of eight clans. Following the historic Mabo case which won recognition for traditional ownership of their land, the Mer people are now fighting for the same recognition of their sea - land and sea are all part of Aboriginal territory and have a historical cultural link to their spiritual beliefs and customs. Their sea is being invaded by commercial fishing fleets and local islanders are struggling to compete - already some have left the Island and three-quarters of the population are on welfare. What has not been resolved by the Mabo case must now be resolved by the Torres Strait Treaty which was designed to protect indigenous rights to fishing and environmental concerns. The documentary presents all sides to the argument including interviews with the commercial fishermen, Mer Island fishermen and community leaders, and legal representatives for the Mer people as well as archival footage of Eddie “Koiki” Mabo discussing sea rights in 1989. Narrated by Aven S. Noah.

constellations_other.name: Setting the record straight
constellations_other.description: For too long, the history of Australia was only told in mainstream films through a white lens. First Nations people have used the camera as a means of truth-telling and setting the record straight for decades.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Autumn Films, SBS Independent, New South Wales Film and Television Office, Australian Film Commission, AFFC, Teresa-Jayne Hanlon and Ivan Sen
results.description:
Ivan Sen’s debut feature continues the story of one of his acclaimed short films, ‘Tears’. Two disaffected teenagers, Vaughn and Lena (played by non-professional actors Damian Pitt and Dannielle Hall), meet on the road as they flee their troubled backgrounds and head to the city. Lena, a light-skinned Aboriginal who passes as white, is looking for the Irish father she only knows from photographs. Vaughn is on the run from a prison farm, going home to see his dying mother who long ago gave him up. He is angry and prone to violent outbursts, especially against white people. Though uncommunicative and wary of each other, the two develop an uneasy, tentative bond as their journey progresses and they encounter various Indigenous and European Australians. With extremely sparse dialogue and little character development, Sen uses visual language to convey the emotional isolation of the pair who are often framed in long shot against the open vistas of the Northern New South Wales rural landscape (shot around Moree), or in extreme close-ups. The chasm between black and white Australia and a continuing history of brutality against Indigenous Australians are underlying themes that run through the film.

Written by Ivan Sen; photography, Allan Collins; music, Alister Spence and Ivan Sen; editing, Karen Johnson.

results.title: Gulpilil: one red blood
results.creator_credit: Jotz Productions, Tom Zubrycki, Darlene Johnson and David Gulpilil
results.brief_description: David Gulpilil is one of the most respected Australian actors of his generation. Born in 1953, he grew up on an Aboriginal reserve and worked as a stockman. Possessing exceptional talents as a dancer, at age 14 he was chosen to play the lead in Nicholas Roeg’s film ‘Walkabout’ (1970). He went on to act in a number of Australian feature films including ‘Mad Dog Morgan’ (1976), ‘Storm Boy’ (1977), ‘The Last Wave’ (1977), ‘Crocodile Dundee’ (1986) and ‘Rabbit-Proof Fence’ (2002). Most recently he won the AFI award for best actor for his performance in ‘The Tracker’ (2002). When he is not acting, Gulpilil lives a demanding traditional life in Arnhem Land, Northern Australia where he is an elder of the Yolngu clan. Following Gulpilil from the set of ‘The Tracker’ back to his community the film reveals how the actor negotiates the two very different worlds he moves between. Interviews with Phillip Noyce, Rolf De Heer, Marcia Langton, Gary Foley, Jack Thompson, and others, as well as with Gulpilil, are interspersed with clips from films in which the actor has appeared.

results.title: One night the moon [DVD] (A)
results.creator_credit: ABC-TV (Australia), Australian Film Commission, New South Wales Film and Television Office, OzOpera, South Australian Film Corporation, Paul Humfress, Kevin Lucas, Aanya Whitehead and Rachel Perkins
results.brief_description: Directed by Rachel Perkins (Radiance), “One night the moon” is the story of a young girl living on an outback station with her parents, who goes missing one evening after becoming enchanted by the moon. After assembling a crew of police and volunteers, the missing child’s racist father will not allow Albert, a gifted Aboriginal tracker, on his land. Albert (Kelton Pell) laments the fate of the helpless child, whose traces are eliminated by the searchers, ruining her chance of survival. Perkins distinguishes this drama by having the majority of the film sung by the principal characters, using minimal dialogue and exposition throughout the narrative. Paul Kelly, who co-wrote the score with Kev Carmody and Mairead Hannan, tackles the difficult character of a bigot, blinded by a prejudice that threatens the life of his daughter. The parents’ marriage cracks under the strains of their child’s fate as the father turns to alcohol for comfort. Filmed in the Flinders Ranges, the cinematography in the film is quite stunning, giving a tremendous sense of the boundless landscape and incredible beauty of the outback. Based on events that occurred in 1932.

results.title: Bush Mechanics
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Warlpiri Media, Australian Broadcasting Corporation, Jennifer McMahon, David Batty and Francis Jupurrula Kelly
results.brief_description: The “Bush Mechanics” comprise of a group of five young Warlpiri Aboriginal men from Yuendumu in the Northern Territory who can face any challenge when it comes to fixing cars, no matter what condition the car may be in! They will use the bush as a resource for spare parts and do whatever it takes to keep a car on the road. Their clever inventiveness, wonderfully offbeat humour and crazy antics, provide an insight into both contemporary and traditional Aboriginal culture. In the style of a road movie, this series follows the “Bush Mechanics” across the central desert, through their many mechanical mishaps, challenges and exploits, including the race to Willowra to play their first paying gig as a rock band, the travel to Alice Springs to collect Simeon’s nephew from jail, the chase for their stolen car and finally covering thousands of kilometers across the west to Broome to search for pearl shells for the rainmaker. The Bush Mechanics are: Simeon Jupurrula Ross, Steven Jupurrula Morton, Errol Jupurrula Nelson, Junior Jupurrula Wilson and Randall Jupurrula Wilson. Also features Jack Jakamurra Ross, and Francis Jupurrula Kelly. In English and Warlpiri with English subtitles.

results.creator_credit: AFTRS, Rachel Roberts, Yvonne Maden and Catriona McKenzie
results.brief_description: An islander Max (Michael Huahihe) finds himself working at a fish processing plant and struggles to be accepted. Unsure of the violent lifestyle, he attempts to move on once given perspective when befriended by Harry (Tony Barry), a local fisherman and his new lover, Phaedra.
